hints.mnemonic: =sun; day： Each time the SUN rises a new DAY begins. day (#12 日) is a picture of the sun. Normally we draw the sun with a circle(ㅇ) surrounded by many strokes. But there are no “round” shaped Kanji so we take mouth (#11 口) instead, and one stroke in the middle (one (#1 一)) representing all. 日本 Japan, 日曜日 （ニチジヨウび）Sunday, 毎日 （マイニチ）everyday, 母の日 （ははのひ）mother's day, 日記 （ニッキ）diary, 三日 （ミッカ）three days.

Also, the mooning "ass" part of it connects well to Hesig's seemingly unconnected "flesh" or "part of the body" meaning (when used in primitive form).

This was to remind them to use the box to measure out their kome for asagohan and ensure their store of rice would last the whole week.

hints.mnemonic: Watch for doctor (#1694 医), the sooner the better! In fact this kanji refers to someone well "learned", with extensive knowledge. This could apply to any kind of field. The kanji 医 ("doctor") is directly related to medicine. I would suggest to take away completely the idea of medicine here, and use a popular character whose name includes the keyword such as "Dr. Who", "Dr. Jekyll", even "Dr. Dobb's" if you're into programming.

They are wise, because they find the pearls of wisdom in the shells of life; 童貞 (virginity); 不貞 (unfaithful); 貞はる (harp too long on a subject); 貞淑 (chastity, virtue); 貞女 (virtuous woman); 不貞寝 (stay in bed out of spite); .

hints.mnemonic: A voice of reason by your side steers you right.

hints.author: notgoing2argue
hints.mnemonic: By my side I POSSESS a  moon of flesh, better known as your big ass!

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: To possess = have or own something. In the fight for survival in prehistoric times, the most important thing to possess was meat by your side which could be eaten at any time. Imagine a caveman after a hunt having meat by his side.

hints.author: Jeromin
hints.mnemonic: The moon stood by my side

hints.author: xzseth
hints.mnemonic: With the moon at my side I transform into a werewolf. Oh no, I am possessed.

hints.author: Jiten

hints.author: martinirwin
hints.mnemonic: If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.

hints.author: ceeeps
hints.mnemonic: In order to bribe me you will have to give me all the clams you possess.

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: A shellfish is not the 'right' possession to bribe with. (It's on the left).

hints.author: Branduil
hints.mnemonic: If money is what possesses you, you will accept many bribes.

hints.author: Aploosh

hints.author: ablindmouse

hints.author: Danieru

hints.author: uberclimber

hints.author: Po0py

hints.author: crazy88

hints.author: stereovibe
hints.mnemonic: To craft a page well, we need paragraphs.

hints.author: martinirwin
hints.mnemonic: Page and craft = pacraft -> paracraft; said properly as paragraph.

hints.author: libsrone
hints.mnemonic: Well, I tried using craft and headings and pages and none of it stuck, so

hints.author: therapysessions
hints.mnemonic: A well CRAFTED PAGE is full of beautiful PARAGRAPHS.

hints.author: romanrozhok
hints.mnemonic: This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.

hints.mnemonic: If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there sword in his ass!

hints.author: fuaburisu
hints.mnemonic: Note

hints.author: thatkidpercy
hints.mnemonic: The part of a sword where a drop of blood can usually be found is the blade.

hints.author: Wosret
hints.mnemonic: A drop of blood on the blade of my sword.

hints.author: Twentytw0
hints.mnemonic: Imagine Blade (Wesley Snipes) wiping the drops of blood from his sword after killing some vampires.

hints.author: canji
hints.mnemonic: How do you know it is a real sword? There is a drop of blood on the blade.

hints.author: jabberwockychortles
hints.mnemonic: There's a drop of blood on the blade of the sword.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The seven samurai used their swords to cut their opponents.

hints.author: phauna
hints.mnemonic: Seven swords cut better than one.

hints.author: dwhitman
hints.mnemonic: The seven samurai used their swords to cut vegetables. (Easier to remember if it's a little silly. Imagine the seven samurai flailing about the kitchen dangerously swinging their katanas about, to cut stuff up for dinner.).

hints.author: ihatobu
hints.mnemonic: Actors filming "The Seven Samurai" respond to the director's command, "CUT!" by wielding their swords.

hints.author: eigoosaka
hints.mnemonic: Be careful!!! Snow White has gone insane and CUT up the SEVEN dwarfs with a DAGGER.

hints.author: arekuru
hints.mnemonic: A man is easily seduced by a mouth to his "sword.".

hints.author: cornrow
hints.mnemonic: When you seduce a girl you can put your sword in her mouth.

hints.author: rakutenka
hints.mnemonic: To seduce is to make a sword of one's mouth.

hints.author: rotifera
hints.mnemonic: To seduce is to accomplish with the mouth what cannot (or should not) be done with a sword.

hints.author: romanrozhok
hints.mnemonic: 召す 【めす】 (v5s,vt) (1) to call; to send for; (2) to put on; to wear; to take (a bath); to ride in; to buy; to eat; to drink; to catch (a cold); (P) This kanji isn't anything sexual or anything. It means SUMMON/TO SEND/CALL FOR (as well as honorific form of eat/drink). STORY

hints.author: erlog

hints.author: bellatora88
hints.mnemonic: Edward Cullen SEDUCES Bella when she sees him SHINING in the SUN. That sparkly bastard.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The knight in shining armour was seduced in just one day.

hints.author: letrange
hints.mnemonic: The Sun Seduces with its Shining light.

hints.author: Raichu
hints.mnemonic: When you have both money and the power of the sword, you can make the rules.

hints.author: ashman63
hints.mnemonic: If you've got CRABs on your SABER, then you didn't follow the rules of safe sex!

hints.author: pazustep
hints.mnemonic: The world is ruled by money and sword.

hints.author: Tobberoth
hints.mnemonic: A shellfish with a sword rules.

hints.author: vgambit
hints.mnemonic: Screw the rules, I have money and a saber.

hints.author: geisel

hints.author: applesuki
hints.mnemonic: Vice-president Cheney

hints.author: demiurge
hints.mnemonic: Vice-President Cheney shot a man in the face while hunting, as is common knowledge, I imagine. So think of it like a Clue answer and you will remember the symbol order as well. One shot, in the mouth, on a field, with a gun (a modern-day sword).

hints.author: Jeromin
hints.mnemonic: The Shogun's second in command, handling the wages

hints.author: frychiko
hints.mnemonic: The VICE president protected my WEALTH with his army of SABER wielding soldiers.

hints.author: leviathan

hints.author: thatkidpercy
hints.mnemonic: A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their mouths bound up to keep them quiet) in a separate room from his sabers. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The prisoner with the BOUND MOUTH was separated from his SABRE.

hints.author: tharvey
hints.mnemonic: They separated me from the group. They gagged my mouth, bound me up, and threatened me with a saber.

hints.author: canji
hints.mnemonic: In Empire Strikes Back, Luke was hanging upside down, muttered with his mouth "Ben, Ben, Ben", his feet bound in ice, he was separated from his light sabre. And he could hear the monster coming for him.

hints.author: steves
hints.mnemonic: Today, the program "Sesame Street" is brought to you by the letter "T".

hints.author: yoshi_features
hints.mnemonic: Two streets make a T-intersection.

hints.author: sethimayne
hints.mnemonic: Any street with nails on it had best be avoided.

hints.author: Daffydus
hints.mnemonic: The street sign is nailed with a spike.

hints.author: rakutenka
hints.mnemonic: The word on the street is, "Mr. T is a bad-ass!".

hints.author: Raichu
hints.mnemonic: Actually this means town, like one that has lots of streets and is surrounded by all the rice fields.

hints.author: meolox
hints.mnemonic: Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. "Pillage the village, for the rice and and the tea." the street primitive on the right looks like a 't'.

hints.author: nilfisq
hints.mnemonic: Note

hints.author: pazustep
hints.mnemonic: Streets through rice fields are only found in small villages.

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: チョウ　まち A village/TOWN is nothing more than rice fields connected by streets.

hints.author: moojitsu
hints.mnemonic: A mouth on the street asking for things

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: I can eat nails.

hints.author: annabel398
hints.mnemonic: On Main STREET America, what you hear in people's MOUTHs is "Yes We CAN!".

hints.author: Phil_Spring
hints.mnemonic: A square box can fit in a corner.

hints.author: stereovibe
hints.mnemonic: Can you speak street? (as in street talk).

hints.author: ceeeps
hints.mnemonic: If I put a street sign on my head what do I get ? A place on the head !

hints.author: Kurisu
hints.mnemonic: NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, The HEAD ON commercial nails it into your head......

hints.author: howdycowdy
hints.mnemonic: You've probably noticed that even the rudest and crudest Japanese say "Itadakimasu" before every meal. Why? Because each person who failed to say it as a child had a nail driven straight into that tender PLACE ON THE HEAD (i.e. the very top of the head). That's a lesson no one will forget!

hints.author: wfreeman
hints.mnemonic: Driving down the STREET, looking at a PAGE in the map, I hit another car, and started bleeding from a place on the head.

hints.author: Matty0187
hints.mnemonic: Nail the page to the wall! Place a Bounty On the head.

hints.author: lbphenom

hints.author: Po0py

hints.author: Jeromin
hints.mnemonic: A child, from one to ten, before becoming a teen.

hints.author: kat1420
hints.mnemonic: To remember strokes

hints.author: DavidZ
hints.mnemonic: L7... To remember the strokes

hints.mnemonic: "Mama" sat on a "shellfish" and it pierced her bottom! Ow!

hints.mnemonic: A teenager addicted to heroine must overcome the needle.

hints.author: Kurisu

hints.mnemonic: Having ten older brothers would be hard to overcome. Ten mouths, and ten sets of legs kicking the crap out of you.

hints.mnemonic: A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he's too little to ride the roller coaster.

hints.mnemonic: Hold something little in-between your fingertips and it'll look like this Kanji here.

hints.mnemonic: Little little little drops...

hints.mnemonic: Ohh, how cute - a little penguin!

hints.mnemonic: Only a few people can make an ugly face like that.

hints.author: Easytarget
hints.mnemonic: A happy grin, after a few drinks.

hints.mnemonic: That playground has a few little ones sliding down the slide.

hints.author: Virtua_Leaf
hints.mnemonic: A few little penguins slide belly-first down an ice slide.

hints.author: pageturner1988
hints.mnemonic: A person stretching their arms and legs to look large and scare a bear away.

hints.author: Teango
hints.mnemonic: How large? This large!

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: Think of a large St. Bernard dog with his paws all stretched out.

hints.author: LeoOra
hints.mnemonic: A person ( 人 -fr.951) showing itself larger widening its arms.

hints.author: xiteru
hints.mnemonic: That volcano is so big, or large, it goes over the clouds (the clouds being the horizontal line).

hints.author: stereovibe
hints.mnemonic: Two evenings too many!

hints.author: scottamus
hints.mnemonic: This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme

hints.author: crystalcastlecreature
hints.mnemonic: These look like the katakana "ta" therefore; There are MANY tatas! WOO~~~!

hints.author: pageturner1988
hints.mnemonic: The ninja waited many evenings for the right moment to strike.

hints.author: FauxSho
hints.mnemonic: Many moons ago.. or perhaps it was just a couple of evenings, I can't remember.

hints.author: stereovibe
hints.mnemonic: The evening is young, the moon is not full.

hints.author: ctalbottclark
hints.mnemonic: In the evening, the crescent moon hangs in the sky.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: In the evening, I try my best to remember the katakana symbol for "TA" (ie. "ta ta!").

hints.author: sprutnik
hints.mnemonic: When I come back home from work in the evening I say tadaima.

hints.author: TerryS
hints.mnemonic: This EVENING, there is only a half-moon.

hints.author: mcdreamer374
hints.mnemonic: Eventide is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.

hints.author: stereovibe
hints.mnemonic: Drops of water shower the beach as the evening tide approaches

hints.author: indigo
hints.mnemonic: Eventide is when the drops of water are attracted to the moon. This is the tide which occurs in the evening.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: In the eventide (nightfall), drops of water start forming in the evening.

hints.author: maikunari
hints.mnemonic: The viking hordes arrive on the eventide, water spashes as the evening sky turn red with blood.

hints.author: Danieru
hints.mnemonic: A young magician likes to practice outside in the evening with his magic wand (as opposed to the old magician who wakes early to practice with his wand in eminent (#51 卓)).

hints.author: jondesousa
hints.mnemonic: Outside in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.

hints.author: toddiceton
hints.mnemonic: Your evening is successful if you get to pull your wand outside your pants.

hints.author: dwhitman
hints.mnemonic: Fairies live outside, and only come out in the evening. When they do, they wave their magic wands as they dance.

hints.author: DavidZ
hints.mnemonic: All the gaikokujin ( 外国人 ="outside country person") guys in Roppongi on a Saturday evening are looking to get their magic wands polished... 外す [はずす] 、外 [そと] 、外国人 [がいこくじん].

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your name so that people can recognise you.

hints.author: panikbuton
hints.mnemonic: In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my name.

hints.author: mspertus
hints.mnemonic: Because it's dark in the evening, you need to open your mouth and speak your name to identify yourself. (This is a traditional mnemonic for this kanji).

hints.author: vinniram
hints.mnemonic: In African tradition, the father sneaks up to the baby in the EVENING, and whispers using his MOUTH the NAME which the baby will carry for his entire life.

hints.author: jay168
hints.mnemonic: My real name is eveningmouth, but you can call me Bob

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of cliff just in time to evade the huge STONE rolling out of the mouth of the cave!

hints.author: Nayelianne
hints.mnemonic: There's a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the cliff thing isn't working for you... Just see it as a stone [いし] being hammered by a miner searching for jewel stones [ほうせき] ;).

hints.author: Uli_S
hints.mnemonic: If you pick the right stone, and hit the kanji 右 right on its head really hard, you can chip off the upper stroke from it.

hints.author: ssavage2004
hints.mnemonic: A mouth (#11 口) open beneath a cliff is bound to swallow some stone.

hints.author: zer0range
hints.mnemonic: A stone covers the entrance to a cave hidden under a cliff.

hints.author: khooks
hints.mnemonic: Using DNA matching, a very little bit of flesh can be used to show the resemblence between family members.

hints.author: Kurisu
hints.mnemonic: Hey baby, it might be a little bit of flesh now, but in a moment it'll bear a strong resemblance to a candlestick.(nudge nudge, wink wink).

hints.author: gaijinda
hints.mnemonic: This kanji bears a resemblance to sparks on a candle. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).

hints.author: FloconDeNeige
hints.mnemonic: あやか-る

hints.author: czaplinsky
hints.mnemonic: God breathing a sparkle of life into flesh to make human resemblant to him.

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured nitrate acid on it.

hints.author: Xtophe
hints.mnemonic: Salpetre is the common name for Nitrate coming from Latin "sal petrae" or stone salt. It is also a component of gun powder so including a candle in this kanji can be quite explosive!

hints.author: nurupo
hints.mnemonic: People I study Kanji with kept talking about some nitrate. I didn't even know what nitrate is, so I hit them with a stone so hard there were sparks flying everywhere. Months later my cell-mate in jail told me it's some sort of acid, but I didn't care any more... Thanks to this Kanji I got 30 years, thank you.

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: That stone resembles nitrate.

hints.author: bakamono
hints.mnemonic: A stone containing nitrate and a candle are not good together.

hints.author: kendobc
hints.mnemonic: To SMASH a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.

hints.author: Shounenbat
hints.mnemonic: The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they've done a new SMASH hit!

hints.author: rotifera
hints.mnemonic: Hulk smash! Hulk smash stone! Hulk decimate stone! What does "decimate" mean, Hulk? Uh, means destroy nine tenths of. SMASH!

hints.author: Clouded
hints.mnemonic: A stone will smash a car-window nine times out of ten.

hints.author: zardoz73
hints.mnemonic: Hulk SMASH! Hulk throw ROCK! Hulk hit 9 people! No! Hulk hit 10 people! Bad people! Hulk smash!

hints.author: mspertus
hints.mnemonic: Here's how I remember that stone is on the left. This is because sand starts as stones, and only later they become few.

hints.author: TerryS
hints.mnemonic: In good SAND, stones are few, if any.

hints.author: nagisa
hints.mnemonic: Over time, rocks are worn down into just a few grains of sand.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: To make sand, start by grinding a few stones.

hints.author: dshill99
hints.mnemonic: Sand has stones few and far between. 砂 【すな】 (n) sand; grit; 砂糖 【さとう】 (n) sugar;.

hints.author: astridtops
hints.mnemonic: The jealous woman bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a stone.

hints.author: oregum
hints.mnemonic: WOMEN are JEALOUS of the STONE on my wife's ring.

hints.author: Neobeo
hints.mnemonic: I'm jealous that my woman has a crush on The Rock.

hints.author: taikura

hints.mnemonic: King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened soil to claim his place as king.

hints.author: TerryS
hints.mnemonic: I tried to stick a needle in the ground but it wouldn't go through the hard SOIL.

hints.author: zoletype
hints.mnemonic: SPIT goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: The only things that come out of my MOUTH and onto the GROUND are spit and vomit. Everything else (words, song) floats on the air.

hints.author: twincy
hints.mnemonic: Means vomit as well. a more decent way to say what you thow up could be "mouth soil".

hints.author: Josh_Teperman
hints.mnemonic: When you get dirt in your mouth, you have to spit it out.

hints.author: smujohnson
hints.mnemonic: Usually when people SPIT, it's because something is LEFT IN THEIR MOUTH ... In that case, they just spit it out.. RIGHT on the GROUND!

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.

hints.author: DrWarrior12
hints.mnemonic: For physics people

hints.author: stereovibe
hints.mnemonic: The cliff exerts a lot of pressure on the ground beneath it.

hints.author: rasteps
hints.mnemonic: The taller the cliff, the more pressure on the soil below it.

hints.author: Ningen
hints.mnemonic: Be careful of landslides! The soil under the cliff is under enormous PRESSURE.

hints.author: frychiko
hints.mnemonic: This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.

hints.author: usis35
hints.mnemonic: Cape Cod "odd" is a land where odd=strange things happen.

hints.author: uchifly
hints.mnemonic: A CAPE is a piece of LAND that stands out STRANGLY in the sea.

hints.author: DrWarrior12
hints.mnemonic: It's quite strange. When I go to Cape Odd, I always end up soiling myself!

hints.author: thegreatkaizo
hints.mnemonic: What the hell does the NASA do at Cape Canaveral? The soil there looks kinda strange...

hints.author: Wahlin
hints.mnemonic: Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: The HEDGE of roses growing from the castle grounds fully spanned the castle walls.

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: The HEDGE spans the GROUNDS of the estate.

hints.author: calittle
hints.mnemonic: The entire grounds were spanned by a hedge.

hints.author: eri401
hints.mnemonic: The kanji also means a fence. Think of a dirt wall that spans your property. 石垣 = いしがき = stone wall.

hints.author: astridtops
hints.mnemonic: In a hole in the ground, the body of the victim was placed. And then the killer stuffed it up so that the truth would not be found out, he hoped.

hints.author: Ragnarocko
hints.mnemonic: I stuffed up his mouth with dirt to keep the truth from coming out.

hints.author: Corodon
hints.mnemonic: There is no grounds for what you are saying. It's not true. You're just making stuff up. I ought to stuff up your mouth to make you STFU.

hints.author: kanjihito
hints.mnemonic: The ground appeared stuffed up with with random deposits, or was it inlaid with the truth of the universe?

hints.author: oregum
hints.mnemonic: I STUFFED DIRT into his mouth to keep the TRUTH from coming to out.

hints.author: Immacolata
hints.mnemonic: Piling SOIL upon SOIL for aeons is how SQUARE JEWELS are formed deep in the earth.

hints.author: mdspencer
hints.mnemonic: How would you stop someone stealing your biggest square jewel? Bury it deep in the soil under ground. Then plant ivy to mark the spot.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: Layering soil over soil can create many things, from precious SQUARE JEWELS to lush beds of ivy.

hints.author: nesert
hints.mnemonic: The pirate wanted to hide his square jewel well. So, he buried it in the soil, under the ground and planted poison ivy over the spot.

hints.author: keizai
hints.mnemonic: Soil upon Soil compressed to make Diamond Square Jewels.

hints.author: Immacolata
hints.mnemonic: The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: A bit of ivy glued to a letter can make a lovely SEAL when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart.

hints.author: tatsuya
hints.mnemonic: Squared jewels with the right measurements receive the jeweler's seal of approval.

hints.author: mafried
hints.mnemonic: Be careful with the order. FIRST you wrap it up in ivy, THEN you seal it with glue.

hints.author: uberclimber
hints.mnemonic: Think of an old book of magic, sealed to prevent it from harming the uninitiated. The sealing spell is contained in a square jewel which is glued to the cover. The cover of the book possibly also has an ivy motif embossed in the cracked leather. 封 ふう sea; 封筒 ふうとう envelope; 封切る ふうぎる release a film; 封建 ほうけん feudalistic.

hints.author: sutebun
hints.mnemonic: Try to reverse Heisig's story in this Kanji

hints.author: jljzen
hints.mnemonic: From the water, I can see the ivy-clad-cliffs on the horizon.

hints.author: romanrozhok
hints.mnemonic: Over the WATER and past the HORIZON there is said to be a CLIFF that holds a very rare JEWEL.

hints.author: mdspencer
hints.mnemonic: Across the water, I can see ivy covered cliffs on the horizon.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: Since Hesig doesn't have another Kanji with the keyword of "shore" it might be worth pointing out to folks here that this is the alternate meaning for this kanji asides from horizon. Also meshes well with Hesig's story spotting those Ivy clad Cliffs on the horizon. Spotting green and beautiful shore-land off in the distance across the water!!

hints.author: ceeeps
hints.mnemonic: At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation.

hints.author: Murjab
hints.mnemonic: To be allowed to join the Buddhist temple, imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the soil for a long time in a measurement of his resolve.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: How long a BUDDHIST TEMPLE has stood on its grounds is often a measure of its worth.

hints.author: scottamus
hints.mnemonic: The Buddhist in the temple sit on the ground for years contemplating life, the universe, and everything. Not because they want to but because someone switched the floor wax with superglue.

hints.author: hornlo
hints.mnemonic: [ Buddhist temple = soil / glue ] - in a Buddhist temple, you can free yourself of the earth that glues you to this world.

hints.author: zdnks
hints.mnemonic: When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it's time to get up.

hints.author: Francois
hints.mnemonic: In ancient Japan, TIME of ''day'' was announced at the ''buddhist temples''. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the time of day.

hints.author: Ningen
hints.mnemonic: A day at a Buddhist temple is TIME well spent.

hints.author: Tatiana
hints.mnemonic: You will fully understand the concept of time if you spend a day in a Buddhist temple.

hints.author: raye505
hints.mnemonic: Time is marked by the sun at buddhist temples.

hints.author: dshill99
hints.mnemonic: Soil is scooped up into a ladel. The extra drop is brushed off to make it level.

hints.author: mafried
hints.mnemonic: To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil fr0m the ladle falling out onto the ground when you level it.

hints.author: trebors
hints.mnemonic: 匀 = equal, not ladle 勺 = ladle. > so the story would be equal soil is equal to leveled ground.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: Kids like scooping dirt with plastic ladles when making mud pies and often sweep off the extra bits of dirt to get it exactly LEVEL.

hints.author: Aerithina
hints.mnemonic: Per LIVELLARE il SUOLO, prendi il MESTOLO e rimuovi quel BRICIOLO/GOCCIA di terreno in piú.

hints.author: munia
hints.mnemonic: For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!

hints.author: raseru
hints.mnemonic: A tepee getting shot at by fire arrows.

hints.author: mistamark
hints.mnemonic: To be honest, it just looks like the flames of a fire to me.

hints.author: LoneDeranger
hints.mnemonic: Looks like a flame of a campfire with two drops of sparks flying off.

hints.author: ryowarrior18
hints.mnemonic: A FIREbender from Avatar, wielding flames in both hands.

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: To fight fire with fire would just inflame a situation.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: An inflammation can often feel like FIRE upon FIRE burning.

hints.author: TerryS
hints.mnemonic: If you have an INFLAMMATION, it feels like there's fire above and below your skin.

hints.author: DrWarrior12
hints.mnemonic: "Inflammable means flammable? What a country!" - from the Simpsons. Saying both flammable and inflammable helps you remember that there are two fires. Inflammation and inflammable have almost the same spelling.

hints.author: ninalaura
hints.mnemonic: When you suffer from a bad inflammation, i.e. an infection, your body will fight it with a high fever. So it fights fire with fire.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: An anxiety feels like FIRE in the HEAD.

hints.author: sethimayne
hints.mnemonic: Imagine the anxiety a librarian would feel if the library caught fire and all the pages of his books were burning up.

hints.author: scottamus
hints.mnemonic: Many performers get "Michael Jackson anxiety" wherein they fear their head will catch on fire.

hints.author: PrettyKitty
hints.mnemonic: In ancient times, they said anxiety was cause by "fire in the head." Picture doctors prescibing many different crazy/silly ways to get the fire out of the patient's head. Now picture it like your watching a documentary on the History Channel about it. Not going to forget it anytime soon now.

hints.author: SammyB
hints.mnemonic: I would be feeling anxiety too if there was a fire on my head!

hints.author: atomiton
hints.mnemonic: Drink water and burn twice as many calories as you eat... you'll definitely get thin. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being burned from above and below... THAT's what it takes to become thin.

hints.author: mezbup
hints.mnemonic: Thin girls are twice as hot when they're wet.

hints.author: sethimayne
hints.mnemonic: To become thin, simply go into a sauna. It may be as hot as a conflagration, but you'll sweat (water) and lose 10 pounds.

hints.author: kaminix
hints.mnemonic: Adding water to an inflammation sure will make it a thin fire.

hints.author: xingji
hints.mnemonic: Water + Fire over fire Faint, pale, fleeting, dim. (NOT THIN!) I remember it using its kun yomi

hints.author: ceeeps
hints.mnemonic: Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.

hints.author: dwhitman
hints.mnemonic: A lamp is fire you can hang from a nail.

hints.author: mdspencer
hints.mnemonic: When this symbol was created, a lamp was simply a fire at the side of the street.

hints.author: Evangelo
hints.mnemonic: Warning

hints.author: ACGalaga
hints.mnemonic: A long time ago they used fire for street lamps.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.

hints.author: CharleyGarrett
hints.mnemonic: When creating a farm, the prospective farmer must first set fire to the forest to clear the ground. Only then can he plow the fields. Fire before fields to make a farm.

hints.author: kashikoi
hints.mnemonic: This kanji actually makes a boatload of sense. In Japan, rice farmers are constantly making little fires on their rice farms burning up all the old stalks and things probably to be used as fertilizer. In moving to Japan, I found this practice to be very new and odd to me. So I would venture to guess that's exactly where this kanji comes from. If not, it certainly makes it really easy to remember.

hints.author: SammyB
hints.mnemonic: Crap! the field in our neighbour's farm is on fire!

hints.author: johngwk
hints.mnemonic: On a Japanese farm, fire is often set to the rice fields (after harvest).

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: What a disaster! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs.

hints.author: Raichu
hints.mnemonic: Don't know about Japan, but here in Australia, flooding rivers and bushfires are the most common natural disasters.

hints.author: colonel32
hints.mnemonic: Godzilla pissing a stream of fire all over Tokyo. That is a disaster!

hints.author: PepeSeco
hints.mnemonic: C-autioun-C-aution-C-aution

hints.author: Marshall3
hints.mnemonic: There's a flood upstairs, and a fire in the basement. I think it's safe to say that this is a disaster.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The fire underneath the cliff will eventually turn everything above to ashes.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: After the cremation fire, many prefer to scatter their loved-one's ASHES from seaside cliffs.

hints.author: fuaburisu
hints.mnemonic: Scene from "The Big Lebowski"

hints.author: kirihitokiri
hints.mnemonic: After fire erupts from under the cliffs (volcano) everything is covered in ashes. Thnx khooks!

hints.author: khooks
hints.mnemonic: After fire erupts from the ground (volcano) the cliffs will be covered in ashes.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.

hints.author: etpan
hints.mnemonic: You have to stimulate the G-spot with your magic wand in order to get her on fire. Or you can juste use your mouth...

hints.author: noushina
hints.mnemonic: The Fortune Teller stares into an Campfire until she sees SPOTS. She then interprets those spots in the same manner than another fortune teller would look at tea leaves or the bumps on your head.

hints.author: kaminix
hints.mnemonic: Alternate meaning of the kanji is mark, or points. Like japanese tests are graded from 0 to 100 depending on how many percent of the questions they got correct. Before I learned any alternate meaning to this I took it as percentage = statistics. Now, wouldn't some pure and concrete statistics be just the thing you need to set that fortune tellers mind on fire? Relate the setting him/her on fire to the entry for anxiety (#163 煩) if it helps.

hints.author: Zarxrax
hints.mnemonic: "Out damn spot!" Yelled the crazy fortune teller as she leaped into the fire. I guess thats not quite how it happened in Hamlet though, so I got a low mark on my English test.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: SHINING FLAMES illuminate!

hints.author: atomiton
hints.mnemonic: The sun was seduced to give us fire, by which we illuminate the night.

hints.author: rotifera
hints.mnemonic: Just shining is not enough to illuminate. The shiny thing needs to be even brighter. Maybe set it on fire?

hints.author: wzafran
hints.mnemonic: You find yourself trapped in an unfamiliar cavern, engulfed in darkness. You wield a Rod of Light with your right hand; its tip is shining, but faintly. Thence, with your other hand, you cast a spell and set fire to the rod. And this rod, which shines with much greater fervour than before, is what would illuminate a path before you, that you then follow until you reach the outer caverns.

hints.author: Shibo
hints.mnemonic: The man who shines shoes in the day stands alone at night in the cold, dark city. He keeps himself warm in front of a burning trash barrel, his face illuminated by the flames.

hints.author: silkcherryblossoms
hints.mnemonic: The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish.

hints.author: tomusan
hints.mnemonic: Bind that FISH and cook his brains! Yarhh!

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: That fish was caught, BOUND UP, then carried across RICE FIELDS, and finally cooked over an OVEN FIRE.

hints.author: DavidZ
hints.mnemonic: Think of (cooked) salmon onigiri. The fish is bound up in rice and cooked over a fire... 魚 [さかな] 、金魚 [きんぎょ] 、魚市場 [おういちば].

hints.author: Keiran_Halcyon
hints.mnemonic: I like my fish bound with rice over a nice fire. Sushi!!

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: You need WATER and FISH for fishing.

hints.author: gorgon
hints.mnemonic: If you are confusing this with angling like me, take fishing to mean not the act of catching a fish but the act of being a fish not living but fishing (i.e. in the water).

hints.author: FuDaWei
hints.mnemonic: "FISHING For Idiots", Chapter One

hints.author: kaminix
hints.mnemonic: What? The fish's still in the water? Well, you better go fishing then!

hints.author: bspitz
hints.mnemonic: Fishing is taking fish out of water.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.

hints.author: DrJones
hints.mnemonic: Hint

hints.author: Bullfrog
hints.mnemonic: It's not just any computer. It's an old Atari.

hints.author: uberclimber
hints.mnemonic: My parents' house is on a rice field; I compute the ground area being one ri by one ri. 古里 (ふるさと)

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: It frustrates me that Hesig doesn't give any mention to another prominent meaning of the 里 / Ri Kanji being used for さと meaning a country village or home. perhaps he thought it would be too confusing for one to remember two different types of villages and distinguish this from 町 ... however... If I think of that one as まち and this one as さと it keeps things straight in my head and allows me to skip the whole confusing path of thinking of this as a "computer" which just seems somewhat wrong.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: If you burn the GROUND of a RICE FIELD with FIRE, eventually it will turn black.

hints.author: ashman63
hints.mnemonic: If your parent's home catches on fire, it will turn black.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: Computer-shomputer... this is a さと（ 里 ）being ravaged by fire... down into charred and burnt blackened remains!

hints.author: johanvg
hints.mnemonic: Rice field ... soil ... fire. Black volcanic soil is perfect for growing rice. It is only logical that farmers regularly burn the brush on their fields in an attempt to imitate nature.

hints.author: Ningen
hints.mnemonic: Burning a computer is ri-diculous. It just leaves everything all BLACK.

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: Theres BLACK on the GROUND...most likely someone spilt some black ink.

hints.author: oliviergirard
hints.mnemonic: Anyone who has worked with laserjet ink cartridges will know the black ink looks like powdered dirt.

hints.author: sprutnik
hints.mnemonic: Black ink comes from black soil.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: Charred bamboo is an essential ingredient in certain types of sumi ink. Imagine that the old さと that burnt down was composed primarily of bamboo houses and structures... thus, residents of the new さと often return to those old grounds to scoop up the charred remains from the soil in order to make thier black ink.

hints.author: lifeflaw
hints.mnemonic: Before mixing with a liquid, black ink looks like black soil!

hints.author: sethimayne
hints.mnemonic: Japanese carp are massive fish - they are measured in ri!

hints.author: colonel32
hints.mnemonic: Robocarp!!! Part fish, part computer! Visualise him flapping and clanking down the street, with bullets richoting off his scaly armour.

hints.author: Branduil
hints.mnemonic: The fish got carpal tunnel syndrome from the computer(I know it's lame but it's hard to find a good story for this).

hints.author: gringozolano
hints.mnemonic: In front of my parents' home is a fish pond full of carp.

hints.author: alanj
hints.mnemonic: Bad pun

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: I did such a quantity of work that when NIGHT BREAK came, I was asleep on the COMPUTER.

hints.author: Murjab
hints.mnemonic: If you find that by nightbreak, you're still playing at your computer, chances are your World of Warcraft character has a high quantity of levels. [thanks to ssmoler] ..... To remember that nightbreak appears ABOVE computer, think of looking UP from your computer at the window to realize you've been playing until nightbreak.

hints.author: johanvg
hints.mnemonic: A quantity can be a measure of time or space (day/ri).

hints.author: krungthep
hints.mnemonic: I have such a huge quantity of kanji to review that night break usually finds me in front of my computer reviewing the kanji.

hints.author: slivir
hints.mnemonic: At nightbreak, it's logical to check the quantity of porn you downloaded to your computer overnight.

hints.author: krungthep
hints.mnemonic: I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it's worth less than a rin.

hints.author: tomusan
hints.mnemonic: A computer dropped off of a cliff would be worth about 1 RIN.

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: The Square Root of 1 RI = 1 RIN.

hints.author: nolusu
hints.mnemonic: He dropped his computer from the top of the cliff and it turned to smithe- rin -s.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: Looking down at the 里 from the high cliff above such a tiny country village looks even smaller like something very very tiny and insignificant... Like a りん / Rin. Also might be worth-while to note now that this isn't just 1/10th of a 銭 but also 1/10th of a 分 or rather... 0.3mm in length. Perhaps imagine holding up a ruler from that high up to measure the tiny speck of a 里 below and note it coming out to 0.3mm in length. ずっとずっと小さいですね～ !!

hints.author: Rowan
hints.mnemonic: You can't bury computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices.

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: I used SOIL to BURY my COMPUTER.

hints.author: uberclimber
hints.mnemonic: Bury me in the soil beside my parents' house. That's where I want to be laid to rest. 埋め込む (うめこむ)

hints.author: DrJones
hints.mnemonic: If you assigned the meaning "House of the Fathers" to ri (#173 里), this one becomes a lot easier. When I die, I want to be buried in these grounds so that my body can find rest at the House of my fathers.

hints.author: dhalprin
hints.mnemonic: When I die, bury me in the soil - next to my computer.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the same, you can just see ONE MOUTH and very little else.

hints.author: ceeeps
hints.mnemonic: Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !

hints.author: mdspencer
hints.mnemonic: One mouth under a hood looks the same as any other.

hints.author: joxn_costello
hints.mnemonic: The cylon warriors all look the same

hints.author: romilmittal
hints.mnemonic: Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the same, you can just see ONE MOUTH and a thin eye line.

hints.author: nolusu
hints.mnemonic: All the animals in the den share the same water.

hints.author: uberclimber
hints.mnemonic: "Den" and "cave" also make me think of a monk's cell. Monks take vows of silence and fast. So a den is where you'd find nothing but water (to drink) and a monk. 洞 ほら cave, den, grotto; 洞窟 どうくつ cave; 洞察 どうさつ discernment; insight.

hints.author: sethimayne
hints.mnemonic: Animals always build their den in the same place - beside the water.

hints.author: Raichu
hints.mnemonic: All those caves were formed by water, and... they all look exactly the same to me!

hints.author: Katsuo
hints.mnemonic: There's a secret den in the monastery where some of the monks hold water-pistol fights.

hints.author: scottamus
hints.mnemonic: A trunk, a trunk // The body of a monk // The body of a monk in a trunk, a trunk.

hints.author: dwhitman
hints.mnemonic: Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. Yes, I'm appalled at how gruesome this story is too.

hints.author: SammyB
hints.mnemonic: The trunk (torso) of everyone's body is mostly the same.

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: Under the MOON the kinky MONKS bare their TRUNKS.

hints.author: jHerbin
hints.mnemonic: Your trunk (torso) is where the body parts meet at the same place.

hints.author: ceeeps
hints.mnemonic: Look over yonder ! That tiny dot is robin hood at the mouth of his secret cave !

hints.author: ashman63
hints.mnemonic: There was an old woman named Wanda,// Who wanted to make herself blonder.// She covered her くち// With a glass hood from Gucci// And dropped some hair dye on from yonder.

hints.author: Ceryn
hints.mnemonic: The spaceman died screaming, his MOUTH wide open because someone has cut the oxygen cable from the HOOD/HELMET of his space suit. As his last DROPs of oxygen escaped into the vastness of space he thought to himself, So much for flying off into the wild blue YONDER.

hints.author: sutebun
hints.mnemonic: Over yonder usually refers to somewhere far away. For this kanji think of the aliens way over yonder who have an antenna popping out of their helmet which encloses but a single mouth.

hints.author: johnzep
hints.mnemonic: Yonder....there is a DOT of light over the mouth of the cave.

hints.author: gaijinda
hints.mnemonic: An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.

hints.author: aircawn
hints.mnemonic: Remember that scene from Star Wars, where Luke is wearing that helmet that only his mouth could see, and was swinging at that little thing buzzing around the room? That was Obi-Wan's trick to get Luke to build his self-esteem, or his confidence in the Force.

hints.author: martinirwin
hints.mnemonic: Little self-esteem is the signature of mouthy teenagers wearing hoodies.

hints.author: SammyB
hints.mnemonic: I have little self-esteem.. so I keep my face under a hood and my mouth shut.

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: I have a small glass box with a mouth inside. I hold this in great esteem, for it is the mouth of my ex and I did the world a great favor by stripping her of it.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE.

hints.author: komodo
hints.mnemonic: "Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father?" "Shut up! It builds character!".

hints.author: axelb
hints.mnemonic: The first kanji characters you will learn in Japan is probably learnt at home (in the house of your family) when you are still a child. Imagine a really small preschool child doing this (to prevent confusing house with school like in study (#324 学)).

hints.author: harusame
hints.mnemonic: The way a child grows up in his house determines his character.

hints.author: applesuki
hints.mnemonic: Imagine a child in his home (under the roof) sitting at the kitchen table practicing his kanji characters.

hints.author: certain
hints.mnemonic: A GUARD is usually "glued" to the house he watches.

hints.author: rakutenka
hints.mnemonic: A guard provides a measure of security to those under a roof.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: A good GUARD should stick to your house like glue and be willing to take any measures to protect you.

hints.author: strobrod
hints.mnemonic: A good guard never leaves the house he watches over. He's practically glued to it.

hints.author: jshield1
hints.mnemonic: A guard gives those under a roof a measure of security.

hints.author: yukina
hints.mnemonic: Make the perfect impression in the beginning by removing your shoes upon entering a Japanese home.

hints.author: timcampbell
hints.mnemonic: In the beginning, Adam and Eve had a home in Eden. It was perfect.

hints.author: kokeshidoll17
hints.mnemonic: Their new house was the perfect place to begin a family.

hints.author: Perry
hints.mnemonic: At the beginning of the party the house was perfect. Now look at it!

hints.author: zanthan
hints.mnemonic: My idea of perfect is just the two of us (human legs) under one roof. Like how it was originally, in the beginning of our relationship. He completes me. 完全 [かんぜん] (adj-na,n) perfection, completeness, (P) 完璧 [かんぺき] (adj-na) perfect, complete, flawless, (P).

hints.author: frychiko
hints.mnemonic: You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: I heard young Muslims have to memorise the Koran and proclaim it aloud as a kind of rite of passage. Imagine the SPAN of hours spent under a ROOF practising that! It must surely be worse than trying to get through Heisigs RTK - count yourself lucky.

hints.author: dwhitman
hints.mnemonic: A local official proclaims a curfew spanning sunset to sunrise - you must stay under your own roof during that time span. I keep wanting to add in the "words" 言 primitive. Don't think about someone reading it aloud - focus on the CURFEW that was proclaimed. I also tend to confuse this one with imperial edict (#342 詔). Remember this proclamation comes from a petty local official.

hints.author: tstuhldreher
hints.mnemonic: I keep thinking about the Irish one-hit band the Proclaimers, who promised to walk 500 miles -- quite a long SPAN -- to reach your HOUSE.

hints.author: Ameyama
hints.mnemonic: Proclaim something loud enough that spans the roof tops.

hints.author: mikes
hints.mnemonic: I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means "early evening", not "wee hours" [Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 "but of course" -- what the hell???). Oh well.] "Every house lights candles in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the wee hours". E.G. 宵の口 （よいのくち）early evening; 今宵 （こよい）this evening; tonight.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: The fixed definition of this Kanji that Hesig gives seems deceptive and misleading. This not only refers to wee hours of the morning but also Evening and Early Night. So it seems to span the whole range of times when one might need a candle to work within the confines of one's house without daylight. Shows me that I can never trust one source of information exclusively, especially not Hesig. I thank him for this sytem of memorization, but still...

hints.author: dingomick
hints.mnemonic: In the log house the wee hours are spent studying by candlelight.

hints.author: krungthep
hints.mnemonic: In the wee hours I usually stay at home lit by a candle playing with my little bit of flesh until it bears resemblance to a candle.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: It's funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive... well... if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman relaxing. Cheapest place to do that is in one's own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? 家で休暇を取るは安いですね。 .

hints.author: enerccio
hints.mnemonic: You can only relax, when you have woman under roof to do all chores.

hints.author: Po0py
hints.mnemonic: Cheapest place for a woman to relax is in her own home.

hints.author: captal
hints.mnemonic: To me, this kanji has always meant "cheap/inexpensive." The way to remember this kanji is

hints.author: mhheie
hints.mnemonic: No one who has ever been to Japan could have failed to notice the relaxed life of the housewifes. While the husband slaves 14 hours a day at work, the woman of the house meets up with friends in cafes, takes piano lessons, goes shopping (no wonder Heizig didn't want to use cheap as keyword), watch TV dramas...oh, and take care of their 1.2 (and going down) children. A woman in a house is the perfect symbol for relax.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The WOMAN spent all DAY preparing a banquet in the HOUSE.

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: Under the roof, all day long, the woman prepared for the banquet (this wording helps me remember the order of this kanji's elements).

hints.author: Katsuo
hints.mnemonic: The woman cannot relax 安 in her house because she only has one day to prepare a banquet.

hints.author: General_Maxon
hints.mnemonic: An entire day of work for the banquet stands between the woman and the relaxation in her house.

hints.author: uchifly
hints.mnemonic: To prepare for a BANQUET, you need to stay in the HOUSE whole DAY, and you need the help of a WOMAN!

hints.author: Danieru
hints.mnemonic: The strange house has a sign saying "DRAW NEAR" in its window, instead of a 'Beware' sign. It must be a trick!

hints.author: pmbeddall
hints.mnemonic: Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The house is very strange. The characters draw near to one another for protection against the unknown.

hints.author: jonny49cc
hints.mnemonic: There is something strange in this house. Do you dare to draw near?

hints.author: dingomick
hints.mnemonic: Hans and Gretel slowly and carefully drew near the strange gingerbread house in the clearing.

hints.author: lexuten
hints.mnemonic: As I draw near, I see something strang in the house.

hints.author: sutebun
hints.mnemonic: Remember Ducktales? That rich duck had that room in his house where he kept all the wealth! He had so much in that house you could even swim in it!

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.

hints.author: taikura
hints.mnemonic: A HOUSE with only ONE MOUTH and a RICE FIELD has a lot of WEALTH.

hints.author: MRT88
hints.mnemonic: The family kept all the wealth under one roof.

hints.author: indigo
hints.mnemonic: Wealth can be assessed only when it's under the roof.

hints.author: pmbeddall
hints.mnemonic: It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.

hints.author: Danieru
hints.mnemonic: My SAVINGS plan - I nail my moneybags up in the rafters below my roof. I'm very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big mustache (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot.

hints.author: trurlo
hints.mnemonic: savings = money kept under the roof rather than spent on the street.

hints.author: CountPacula
hints.mnemonic: Savings are the clams you have nailed down under your roof.

hints.author: dihutenosa
hints.mnemonic: A slightly smarter guy has all of his SAVINGS - in the form of shells - nailed up just under the eaves of the floating roof.

hints.author: liosama
hints.mnemonic: If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.

hints.author: beth266
hints.mnemonic: Pictograph of a tree.

hints.author: fiminor
hints.mnemonic: As a primitive, I often use Tolkein's Ents as they have more scope for adventure than ordinary inanimate trees.

hints.author: pjdekl
hints.mnemonic: http

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: [Cheat] Remember these as a set

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: A grove has at least two TREEs.

hints.author: coolbananas
hints.mnemonic: If you need a mnemonic to remember this then you had better give up now!

hints.author: hornlo
hints.mnemonic: [ grove = tree + tree ] - a grove is between a single tree (#195 木) and a many-treed forest (#197 森).

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: Two trees together make up a GROVE.

hints.author: romanrozhok
hints.mnemonic: "I must...safe guard the GROVE" says the Keeper of the Grove as he uses his treant ability to cast TWO TREE minions. (warcraft III reference).

hints.author: sharak10
hints.mnemonic: The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that's so u dont mess up with their possition like i do.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: Another tree planted within a grove turns it into a FOREST.

hints.author: axisj
hints.mnemonic: Many Trees make a forest.

hints.author: KREVA
hints.mnemonic: A triangle of trees is all that's needed to depict a forest.

hints.author: Kimya
hints.mnemonic: A triforce of trees makes a forest.

hints.author: fuaburisu
hints.mnemonic: Simple mnemonic

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: A tree covered in poison ivy will quickly betray you, thus the name JAPANESE JUDAS-TREE.

hints.author: kaminix
hints.mnemonic: The Katsura (Japanese Judas-tree) is a thin tree (sort of like the stretched out 木 used in this kanji) with little green (the color of an emerald, a jewel) leaves. http

hints.author: romanrozhok
hints.mnemonic: Japanese JEWEL TREE sounds like JUDAS-tree.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: Interesting... this tree is called a かつら (Katura) Tree in Japan. It got the Japanese Judas-Tree distinction because it bears a similar leaf-type to the Judas Tree found in Europe and such. For fun word-play with both the Judas & Katsura distinctions... it might be good to learn that a homonym for Katsura (w/different Kanji 鬘) is a hairpiece or wig! So now imagine some dishevled business man with a funny hairpiece stringing ivy around the Katsura/Judas tree to hang himself with!!

hints.author: lilpea
hints.mnemonic: The wood from oak trees can be used to make barrels in which white wine is aged. What's more, I love white wine with an oaky flavour...

hints.author: ashman63
hints.mnemonic: An oak tree is white, from left to right!

hints.author: Mesqueeb
hints.mnemonic: [Pokemon] Ash

hints.author: lbphenom
hints.mnemonic: The white tree of Minas Tirith was an oak!

hints.author: Raichu
hints.mnemonic: Prof. Oak ( オオキド博士 to Japanese fans) is named after a tree and has white hair.

hints.author: alkulp
hints.mnemonic: wood at 90 (9 * 10) degrees.

hints.author: javiergakusei
hints.mnemonic: Nine out of ten picture frames are made out of wood. The rest are made of metal or plastic.

hints.author: uberclimber
hints.mnemonic: A good wooden frame has perfect right angles at each corner

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: Nine-tenths of all frames are made of wood (9 over 10).

hints.author: Es2Key
hints.mnemonic: Wooden frame 9x10.

hints.author: sethimayne
hints.mnemonic: At Christmas time, on the treetops, people used to place great big candles (Now we usually place a star instead).

hints.author: Tatiana
hints.mnemonic: If you cut off the treetops, they still resemble the trees they used to be part of. Treetops=tree resemblance.

hints.author: astgtciv
hints.mnemonic: A gigantic candle is standing to the right of the tree, the flame rising higher than the treetops.

hints.author: Ji_suss
hints.mnemonic: Doesn't really mean treetops. It means the end of a branch. In English, the name for each year's new growth at the end of every branch is a "candle". Same in Japanese.

hints.author: LeoOra
hints.mnemonic: The tops of the trees, as in the fractal theory, resembles a whole tree if you look from afar.

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: A shelf is a wooden companion to books.

hints.author: TaylorSan
hints.mnemonic: I think of an Otaku, with a wooden shelf full of anime action figure statures, who are sadly his only companions.

hints.author: komodo
hints.mnemonic: My ideal companion would have an ass I could use as a shelf. Just look at those two fleshy hemispheres. The association of wood should come easily.

hints.author: joxn_costello
hints.mnemonic: A shelf is made out of wood, and it is a companion to books. But most importantly for me, the two moons look like the spines of hardbound books standing next to one another as companions on a shelf.

hints.author: terozen
hints.mnemonic: A wooden shelf is the perfect companion to all my lovely books!

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: From the tree straight into the mouth is the best way to eat an APRICOT!

hints.author: thegeezer3
hints.mnemonic: Imagine Totoro sleeping under his tree. As he snores a giant apricot falls nicely into his open mouth and he emits a giant burp of satisfaction. I can hear that music alreay....to - to to - to - ro...

hints.author: DrWarrior12
hints.mnemonic: If you eat apricots too fast, you'll end up eating the pits too. And we all know what happens then - an apricot tree will grow out of your mouth.

hints.author: oohansel
hints.mnemonic: The apricot fell from the TREE into my MOUTH.

hints.author: jabberwockychortles
hints.mnemonic: I lay under the apricot tree and let the delicious apricots drop into my mouth.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the "princess tree". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her.

hints.author: akira
hints.mnemonic: Paulownia is a Japanese tree which looks same as any other tree.

hints.author: zardoz73
hints.mnemonic: In the forest, there's a tree that my goofy friend PAUL claims he OWNS. I think he's nuts, because the tree looks the SAME as all the others.In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the "princess tree".

hints.author: totokan
hints.mnemonic: Also called Phoenix tree. After the wood is harvested the tree regenerates from its roots. The same tree comes up again.

hints.author: gagge_tah
hints.mnemonic: Paul owns the same tree as everyone else, a paulownia. // not every tree as in plum (#460 梅).

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: Plants don't become trees straightaway.

hints.author: liosama
hints.mnemonic: When you plant plants, you use a piece of WOOD to make the plant grow STRAIGHT.

hints.author: sutebun
hints.mnemonic: If you get a new tree it is of course best to go plant it straightaway. Without planting it straightaway the roots won't have enough time to be healthy and strong like the tree needs.

hints.author: JohninJapan
hints.mnemonic: PLANT a TREE with tottoro and it might start growing STRAIGHTAWAY. (see tonari no tottoro

hints.author: kuraujiokun
hints.mnemonic: To plant

hints.author: ikmys
hints.mnemonic: To the Japanese, the first time they saw a chair, it looked like a strange use of wood! Probably why they still like to sit on the floor...

hints.author: Earthlark
hints.mnemonic: Http

hints.author: Katsuo
hints.mnemonic: A strange kind of tree grows in the shape of a chair.

hints.author: blannk
hints.mnemonic: Traditionally a wooden chair would have been a strange object in a Japanese home.

hints.author: KanjiVirtuoso
hints.mnemonic: Wooden rocking chairs must've seemed pretty strange to those seeing them for the first time.

hints.author: sutebun
hints.mnemonic: A tree withers away as it gets old.

hints.author: Danieru
hints.mnemonic: When flowers get old they suffer (frame 225), but old trees just WITHER away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad).

hints.author: Kurisu
hints.mnemonic: The tree is old and withered.

hints.author: chibimizuno
hints.mnemonic: I had trouble remembering this one using tree and old, so I just thought of what the wood of an old man would look like, and that did the trick.

hints.author: gorgon
hints.mnemonic: When flowers get old they are said to be suffering (225) but there is no sympathy for the poor old tree which simply withers!

hints.author: simple
hints.mnemonic: Wooden wands are the crudest. They are nothng compared to their carbon fibre equivilents.

hints.author: wingedge
hints.mnemonic: A beginner magician starts with a crude wooden magic wand. Later he'll upgrade to magicite, of course.

hints.author: Harrow
hints.mnemonic: You can make a crude magic wand from any tree.

hints.author: chibimizuno
hints.mnemonic: First year boys at Hogwarts tend to compare their wood to their wand, but this is considered crude behavior.

hints.author: RobMow
hints.mnemonic: This guy is so crude he doesn't face the tree when he relieves himself.

hints.author: zhangqiezi
hints.mnemonic: If you've ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you'll remember that every town was all bordered off by a line of trees with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were glued together so you could only exit town through the main or side gates, (so you couldn't escape the important scripted scenes.).

hints.author: Virtua_Leaf
hints.mnemonic: Pfft. At it's core, a town is just a bunch of wood glued together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD.

hints.author: Sunday
hints.mnemonic: There is a mix up, this kanji means むら=village, not town. The one for town is まち　= 町 . 100% shure because my teacher is native Japanese.

hints.author: Kieron
hints.mnemonic: I swap the town/village keywords. See also village (#92 町). As the old Siberian joke went, there's nothing to do in a small rural village but count (measure) the trees.

hints.author: MikeNeko
hints.mnemonic: 村 means village! See village (#92 町). Please don't get them confused like Heisig seems to have done. Story

hints.author: ashman63
hints.mnemonic: The prime minister is having inter-course behind that tree! All you can see are his eyes poking out from the righthand-side of the tree.

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. "Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other's aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck ( 首 , neck (#70 首)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)".

hints.author: gaijinda
hints.mnemonic: I changed my story to remind myself there are other primary meanings for this character

hints.author: Ameyama
hints.mnemonic: A piece of wood went "inter" my eye. This is an internal injury.

hints.author: meredithcat
hints.mnemonic: Intercourse usually occurs between two people lying beneath a tree, gazing into each other's eyes.

hints.author: Kieron
hints.mnemonic: My wooden desk is so messy, it looks like a strong wind blew my things all over it.

hints.author: Elphalpo
hints.mnemonic: Whenever I'm alone at my computer desk, I'm always getting wood and breaking wind.

hints.author: shimouma
hints.mnemonic: The tree was blown down by the wind - so I made a desk from it.

hints.author: Danieru
hints.mnemonic: Studying at my wooden desk, a great wind sweeps away all my papers - there goes all my hard work - I can see all the kanji disappearing into the sky.

hints.author: trikatu
hints.mnemonic: A tree blown over in the wind makes a desk.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The origin of a book is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many books.

hints.author: ggwar
hints.mnemonic: A book is one slice of a tree.

hints.author: burento5
hints.mnemonic: An axe cutting a tree to make books.

hints.author: johanvg
hints.mnemonic: Books are the root of all knowledge (in Chinese this character means root or basis).

hints.author: Raitasar
hints.mnemonic: Sad 'Fact'

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.

hints.author: elktapestry
hints.mnemonic: Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for "Paper Money" w/ the reading さつ ( 千円札＝ 1000 Yen paper bill)... It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 ("trump" playing cards). For the tag meaning I like to think of wooden tags hung on hooks from trees... but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to "hook you in" so to speak.

hints.author: peepiceek
hints.mnemonic: In order to put a tag on a tree you need a hook.

hints.author: xxinde
hints.mnemonic: A tag was hooked on a tree. Since the tag was actually a banknote (さつ), it's no wonder that it's gone now and only the hook remains sticking out from a tree.

hints.author: certain
hints.mnemonic: A little piece of paper (wood) attached by a hook makes a TAG.

hints.author: Danieru
hints.mnemonic: Years-Months-Days

hints.author: cbogart
hints.mnemonic: This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: You can use a calendar to count the number of DAYs it takes to grow two TREES under a CLIFF.

hints.author: taikura
hints.mnemonic: Calendar; almanac. A calendar measures time in years, months and days. A cliff (厂) takes years to form; a grove ( 木木 ) of trees takes months to grow; but the sun ( 日 ) rises and falls every day. All of these periods can be recorded in a calendar.

hints.author: Ningen
hints.mnemonic: I love those nature CALENDARs with all the photos of cliffs and trees and the setting sun.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.

hints.author: MichaelAnd
hints.mnemonic: If you bring a woman to your house, generally its not a good plan to stick your wood up her bottom, she may scream in pain あん!

hints.author: dziewuliz
hints.mnemonic: Man's plan of life

hints.author: Danieru
hints.mnemonic: Calvin and Hobbes sit in their treehouse, which has a big "no girls" sign on it, deviously making their PLAN for their next water-balloon attack against the 'stinky girls'.

hints.author: DrWarrior12
hints.mnemonic: How can you relax when you have a tree jammed up your ass?! Quickly make a plan to get down from there!

hints.author: Katsuo
hints.mnemonic: Tip

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The parchment says you need fire to make goods from trees.

hints.author: crayonmaster
hints.mnemonic: When a FIRE is parched, it isn't thirsty for water, it wants to gobble up some WOODEN GOODIES!

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: ソウ "A fire's heat will parch/dry out any goods made from wood." E.G. 乾燥する （かんそう・する）to dry up.

hints.author: LazyNomad
hints.mnemonic: Hint

hints.author: dat5h
hints.mnemonic: I believe a better version of that by mameha1977

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: [Cheat] Remember these as a set

hints.author: DeadLugosi
hints.mnemonic: This TREE is not yet fully grown

hints.author: Ameyama
hints.mnemonic: "Have you sawed off those two smaller branches at the top of the tree?" "Not yet...".

hints.author: squeaky_lill_mk
hints.mnemonic: The top branch of the tree is not yet as long as the bottom one.

hints.author: amema
hints.mnemonic: The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.

hints.author: Shibo
hints.mnemonic: There are no great stories for this one yet, and I always forget it.. So, let's try something ridiculous

hints.author: Dualta
hints.mnemonic: The tree's top branches have grown to extremities.

hints.author: NyahK
hints.mnemonic: Another version of that by mameha1977 and dat5h

hints.author: arthur
hints.mnemonic: It's near the upper extremity of the tree that grows the larger branches.

hints.author: Aerin
hints.mnemonic: Something that is obscure has not yet been brought before the light of day.

hints.author: to_nihon
hints.mnemonic: 'Can't you go outside and get some sun?' 'Not yet, I have to learn all these obscure RTK3 kanji!'.

hints.author: mantixen
hints.mnemonic: Things look obscure when the sun is not yet out.

hints.author: decals
hints.mnemonic: Unlike us, some people finish RTK 1 and think "Should I learn all those obscure kanji in RTK 3? Nah, NOT YET. I'll learn them some other DAY." We're just extra Kanji sadistic. (Although, I should say, this kanji is not very obscure. 曖昧 is in the vocab list for JLPT level 2).

hints.author: FoxintheStars
hints.mnemonic: An obscure artist or personage is one whose day in the sun has not yet come.

hints.author: dwhitman

hints.author: gametip
hints.mnemonic: A splash is WATER that has reached its EXTREMITY.

hints.author: nolusu

hints.author: raijne

hints.author: tharvey
hints.mnemonic: My younger sister is a woman who is not yet fully grown.

hints.author: daredawg3583
hints.mnemonic: My younger sister is not a girl, but NOT YET a woman (Brittany Spears).

hints.mnemonic: It's autumn

hints.author: solarmist
hints.mnemonic: [Cheat] Remember these as a set

hints.mnemonic: [Cheat] Remember these as a set

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: [Cheat] Remember these as a set

hints.mnemonic: Which tree would you buy stocks in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one vermilion leaf left on the right?

hints.author: ihatobu
hints.mnemonic: Ideally, one buys stocks when a company is young, "green," and rapidly growing -- then sells them just before the last vermillion leaf falls off, and a period of dormancy or limited growth begins.

hints.author: shimouma
hints.mnemonic: I have a hot tip for you. Buy stocks in a company called "Tree and Vermillion Ltd".

hints.author: CarlKenner
hints.mnemonic: Don't think of the stock-market. Instead imagine the wooden medieval stocks used to hold a prisoner's head and hands between two blocks of wood. The wood in this case is vermilion coloured, as it often was. Imagine SHOOING away the guards and blowing the stocks open with a big "kaboom" sound. (ON reading SHU, Kun reading kabu).

hints.author: oRis1024
hints.mnemonic: You buy stocks when they're new and green like a normal tree and sell it when it's vermillion-HOT and pricy.

hints.author: Ramchip
hints.mnemonic: The young little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.

hints.author: kat1420
hints.mnemonic: Young love puts a flower in her right hand (true love puts a ring on her left!!).

hints.author: Kurisu
hints.mnemonic: Imagine Alice reading a note in Wonderland

hints.author: gaboblar
hints.mnemonic: Young people are always right.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: Ah, young love! A man holding FLOWERs (well, better than GRASS) in his RIGHT hand.

hints.author: dicedice
hints.mnemonic: Grass grows in earlier than flowers.

hints.author: Katsuo
hints.mnemonic: This grass is very long. The only flowers you can see are sunflowers – the rest are hidden by the grass.

hints.author: sethimayne
hints.mnemonic: My Dad always made me cut the grass early in the morning - it sucked.

hints.author: kanjihito
hints.mnemonic: Grass grows early, before the flowers which eventually grow above.

hints.author: vertigo959
hints.mnemonic: My Dad said "Cut the grass early, and watch out for the FLOWERS!!!". ソウ 草履。くさ .

hints.author: applesuki
hints.mnemonic: Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.

hints.author: PepeSeco

hints.author: MichaelAnd
hints.mnemonic: Old people smoke pot to ease their suffering.

hints.author: atomiton
hints.mnemonic: FLOWERS SUFFER when they grow OLD. Trees slowly wither( 枯 ) and die. I find I can remember these together.

hints.author: salvw

hints.mnemonic: 苛める （いじめる） "If you don't give me those flowers, I'll drive this spike into your mouth.".

hints.author: CountPacula
hints.mnemonic: Flowers, you ask if they can feel pain, do you? ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ They sure -can-!! ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^!!

hints.author: kanjihito
hints.mnemonic: "With flowers, I think I can stop the bullying," said the Little Engine that Could. Indeed the bullying stopped, as the tormentors were covered by a trainload of flowers.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: A tolerant person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend.

hints.author: saruwatari
hints.mnemonic: To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning "beautiful things") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.

hints.author: Ningen
hints.mnemonic: Kanji Zen

hints.author: Foddy
hints.mnemonic: My wife grows flowers in the house and I see them every day. I don't really like them, but I have to be tolerant.

hints.author: axelb
hints.mnemonic: Into my house someone brought a monstrous flower with a big, walking eye, seeing everything, like a spy. But I am trying to be tolerant, although it is getting on my nerves. Remember

hints.author: gaijinda
hints.mnemonic: A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine.

hints.author: pm215
hints.mnemonic: [As suggested by stehr and on the forum (http

hints.author: stehr
hints.mnemonic: Note This character belongs to a set of characters which share the flower/water primitive such as

hints.author: wzafran
hints.mnemonic: A man with thick blood dripping out of his hands visits an acupuncturist. "Please dilute my blood!" he says. The acupuncturist gives the man a seat, punctures his skin with many flower stems, and inserts a drop of cold water through the holes at the top of those stems. The man's blood becomes soft pink in colour . As too much blood had been diluted, he dies.

hints.author: AndamanIslander
hints.mnemonic: A homeopathy specialist takes flowers and dilutes them in some water... (picture my hippie aunt with her homeopathist diluting flowers in water.).

hints.author: nolusu
hints.mnemonic: On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below.

hints.author: shimouma
hints.mnemonic: The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.

hints.author: Katsuo
hints.mnemonic: Tip

hints.author: uchifly
hints.mnemonic: A LEAF is like a FLOWER that lasts only one GENERATION on a TREE and then it dies.

hints.author: nesert
hints.mnemonic: The flower generation were leaf smoking tree-huggers.

hints.author: Elphalpo
hints.mnemonic: If I find out this furniture you're selling me is made of imitation wood, I'll put you in the graveyard.

hints.author: Ninjasha
hints.mnemonic: The Japanese are so enamored of everything plastic, they even put IMITATION plastic trees in their graveyards! (No, not really, but I wouldn't be surprised).

hints.author: elanlan
hints.mnemonic: This kanji was a real asshole. No one liked this kanji. That is why that when this kanji died, no one cared, and it received a wooden, imitation tombstone; not a fancy marble one, at its resting place in the graveyard.

hints.author: peepiceek
hints.mnemonic: The imitation tree looked like a big sun flower.

hints.author: Ricardo
hints.mnemonic: imitation

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague.

hints.author: jjazz_kanji_first
hints.mnemonic: The water in the graveyard has worn away the headstones, so the writing is vague.

hints.author: nicjsb
hints.mnemonic: Vague, vague, watery grave. (Repeat this phrase several times).

hints.author: roderik
hints.mnemonic: Water and graveyard can only result in a vague mnemonic for this kanji.

hints.author: akimoto
hints.mnemonic: The mist and fog surrounding the graveyard make things appear vague and unfamiliar.

hints.author: simple
hints.mnemonic: The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.

hints.author: mameha1977
hints.mnemonic: A grave is a patch of soil in a graveyard.

hints.author: johanvg
hints.mnemonic: Graves are in the soil beneath the graveyard.

hints.author: Cirion
hints.mnemonic: The flowers were blooming, the sun was shining, when I let my St. Bernard off his leash and he lifted his leg and peed ON some freshly turned soil that was dug out for a grave. [Thanks to dwhitman for the idea of the peeing dog because the way the last stroke for 大 is shifted rightwards would mess me up, but if the dog's got his leg up in the air... it's a nice visual image for the change from the primitive graveyard.).

hints.author: stungunjones
hints.mnemonic: The soil under the Kakariko graveyard is full of many more things than graves.

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.

hints.author: Ryuujin27
hints.mnemonic: I like trikatu's simple way to remember this, but just in case the primitive placements confuse you, change it around to this

hints.author: dwhitman
hints.mnemonic: The gravedigger makes his LIVELIHOOD digging in the graveyard all day For graveyard, imagine an idyllic picture

hints.author: trikatu
hints.mnemonic: Before you complain about your livelihood, think about spending your days in a graveyard.

hints.author: uchifly
hints.mnemonic: You have to earn a LIVELIHOOD until you go to the GRAVEYARD, when your DAYS are over, and your SUN went down...

hints.author: notgoing2argue
hints.mnemonic: In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss.

hints.author: calittle
hints.mnemonic: The membranes in your flesh rot when placed in the graveyard.

hints.author: PeterJD
hints.mnemonic: マク Membranes (thin layers of connective tissue) are the part of the body that decompose first (i.e., before the organs, ligaments, bones, etc.) after one dies and is buried in a graveyard.

hints.author: Harrow
hints.mnemonic: The membrane between the dead and the living is thinnest in a graveyard in moonlight.

hints.author: Kurisu
hints.mnemonic: Flesh eaten by zombies in the graveyard is mem~brai~ns!!!

hints.author: Christine_Tham
hints.mnemonic: If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.

hints.author: SammyB
hints.mnemonic: Crap! There are flowers in the rice field... Who let those seedlings get in there?!

hints.author: tanaquil
